summary: This is an email chain from April 7, 2021, between Assistant United States Attorneys (AUSAs) and likely FBI agents, detailing the logistical plan for the defense team's physical evidence review in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It outlines the schedule, locations (500 Pearl Street courthouse and a Bronx warehouse), security protocols, and evidence handling procedures.

persons.name: Maxwell
persons.context: Ghislaine Maxwell, the accused, is to be produced daily from custody to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse for her defense team's evidence review. She will be monitored by an FBI agent.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The primary author of the detailed email outlining the evidence review plan. They are coordinating logistics between the FBI, defense team, and court, and will field defense questions during the review.

connections.person1: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Prosecutor coordinating the legal process and evidence review for the defendant, Maxwell.

events.title: Start of Maxwell Defense Evidence Review
events.description: The primary evidence review for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is scheduled to begin at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse. It will continue daily until complete.
personsInvolved: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York

locations: 500 Pearl Street courthouse (5th floor proffer room area)
keyFacts: A detailed logistical plan was created for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team to review physical evidence, starting April 13, 2021, at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse.
Maxwell was to be produced daily from Marshal custody and monitored by an FBI agent with a handcuff key, including escorting her to the bathroom.
Evidence included highly confidential images from CDs and from Jeffrey Epstein's devices that the defense had not yet reviewed.
A separate review at a Bronx warehouse was also planned for evidence not brought to the courthouse, with the defense permitted to photograph certain items.
The email highlights the extensive coordination between AUSAs and the FBI to facilitate the defense's access to evidence while maintaining security and chain of custody.
